13.59.text: It looks pretty good, doesn't it?

15.42.text: A tall glass of milk and an Oreo cookie.

18.52.text: I know we just had lunch,

19.73.text: but how many of you guys

20.87.text:
could go for for milk and cookies
right now?

26.12.text:
I find the position
of that particular Oreo

31.33.text:
perfectly balanced
on the edge of the glass.

34.77.text:
I guess balance is something
we all hope to achieve

37.28.text: and maintain at some point in our lives,

40.25.text: but, as a freshman in high school,

45.58.text:
I took a plunge into that huge
glass of milk we call life

49.58.text: and the results was a soggy Oreo,

52.87.text: barely keeping its head above water.

58.09.text: and made it back to the top of the glass,

60.78.text:
but not before learning
a few lessons about life

68.03.text:
I learned a very different definition
of the word Oreo,

72.11.text: not the sweet cookie we all know and love,

77.94.text:
an insulting term, often used by blacks
to derogate other blacks,

83.71.text:
as black on the outside,
but white on the inside,

88.53.text: white on the inside meaning anything,

94.76.text:
liking music that isn't necessarily
hip-hop or rap

98.32.text: and having a diverse group of friends.

101.34.text:
Now, when I first read the definition
of this insult online,

105.16.text:
I thought, "I can't argue.
This is a spot-on description of me."

111.25.text:
So, when my friends began, jokingly,
calling me "the Oreo,"

118.17.text:
But, over time, the Oreo mantra
became less of a joke

123.03.text:
and more of a blind description
of my personality,

127.94.text:
and I became nothing more
than what you see here,

133.57.text:
not the fun-loving girl who liked
to read and write,

136.81.text: but the girl who was black,

142.27.text: Because, you see, I can't dance.

146.93.text:
I don't play any sports,
but I'm on speech team

149.93.text: and I do speak proper English.

153.03.text:
I was criticized for not liking
watermelon or Kool-Aid,

158.29.text:
and, on the one day that I did decide
to eat fried chicken at lunch,

162.32.text: my friend turned to me and said,

167.37.text:
And this type of blind prejudice
and stereotyping

174.90.text:
That label could,
just as easily, say "gay,"

181.23.text:
In fact, I'm sure you've all heard
the cliche phrase,

185.79.text:
in reference to something
that seems silly or weird.

189.76.text:
And I'm sure everyone in this room
is guilty of using the word "retarded"

198.36.text:
and Muslims toting bombs
beneath their turbans

205.15.text: And I stand before all of you today

207.53.text:
to let you know that that was not
and never will be OK.

216.00.text:
Former president Henry A. Wallace
once said,

219.12.text:
"It may be shocking to some people
in this country

222.45.text:
to realize that, without meaning to do so,
we hold views in common with Hitler

230.36.text:
against other racial, religious
and economic groups."

235.13.text:
And as shocking and unnerving
as it may sound,

239.34.text:
when we make those hateful comments
and laugh at those hateful jokes,

243.78.text: we are no better than Hitler.

247.61.text:
When we preach discrimination
against others,

250.26.text:
based on their race, religion,
sexuality or gender,

255.42.text:
we lose a decade of progress
toward equality,

259.22.text: and if we keep moving in this direction,

262.37.text:
we will never make it out
of the 19th century.

267.33.text:
In 1953, the color TV
was introduced worldwide.

271.87.text:
Long gone were the days
of viewing the world in black and white.

277.65.text:
Yet, people continued to view real life
with a black-and-white filter.

286.16.text:
we live in 1080p stunning,
high-definition color.

292.19.text:
Isn't it about time we start
opening up our eyes

297.86.text:
to see the truly beautiful human being
that lies within all of us?

306.47.text:
when you're walking into a room
for the first time

313.04.text: Are you seeing the blacks and the whites,

321.51.text:
Or are you seeing the philosophers
and the daydreamers,

332.27.text: Are you seeing the vapid, colorless past

336.15.text: or the bright and shining future?

342.88.text:
whether you are black, white,
blue or green,

348.27.text: an Oreo cookie, a red velvet cookie

352.89.text: whether you are gay or straight,

354.94.text:
whether you worship Allah,
Buddha or Bieber,

360.55.text: it's time for us to all take a moment

362.80.text:
to think about how our actions
affect others.

366.88.text: It's time to take the silent stand

369.61.text: and send the message that words,

372.40.text: no matter how small they may seem,
